awd_abstract_narration:
Through the Facilitated Access to Science Training (FAST) project the Principle Investigator team at the University of Texas at San Antonio seeks to increase the number of economically disadvantaged students who complete biology, chemistry, or physics degrees and proceed to enter the scientific workforce or pursue advanced studies.  The project requires 13 participants to take part in activities designed to help them find support, build relationships with faculty mentors, and strengthen their self-efficacy and self-identity as scientists.  A unique feature of the plan is an intensive one-week, pre-college science boot camp that focuses on providing students with foundational knowledge in subject areas in which they are deficient and introduces them to scientific thinking.  In order to broaden participation, students are recruited from the greater San Antonio area which is 70% Hispanic and African American.

Throughout the project, S-STEM scholars (a) develop academic excellence and independence as they proceed through gatekeeper and advanced courses, (b) enhance their competence as scientists by connecting with a mentor, (c) participate in scientific research, and (d) engage in professional and personal enrichment activities including participation in scientific conferences. The program builds on current, successful initiatives including the implementation of evidence-based practices in gateway courses and recruitment of undergraduates from the university's college preparatory program.  Data generated through assessment and evaluation supports the rationale that this three-pronged approach of providing students with a support structure, faculty mentors, and helping them to become self-identified scientists leads to retention and graduation.  Formative and summative evaluation focuses on assessment of student confidence, academic aspirations and expectations, and career development.  The students are also tracked and interviewed about the project's impact.  Dissemination of the project results provides a model for strengthening self-efficacy and self-identity as a means of retaining STEM students.  The project team plans to present their work through the Annual Conference on Understanding Interventions that Broaden Participation in Research Careers as well as through national meetings of the American Chemical Society and the AAAS.  Project deliverables will include results of summative evaluation and the course materials developed for the boot camp.

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio

por.por_cntn:
The FAST program was an NSF S-STEM (Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) project which took place at the University of Texas at San Antonio from 2014 – 2021. The goal of this project was to increase the number of economically disadvantaged students who complete Biology, Chemistry, or Physics undergraduate degrees and who proceed to the scientific workforce or pursue advanced studies in STEM areas. To achieve this goal, the FAST program provided scholarship support as well as mentoring and development activities to students.

Throughout the duration of the FAST program, thirty-four economically disadvantaged students in total were recruited in five cohorts spanning five years through a competitive application process. (The final recruited cohort entered the program in Fall 2019.) The first four cohorts were made up of first-year students; the final cohort was made up of more advanced students. During their time in the FAST program, these students received academic scholarships, as well as one-on-one academic advising and mentoring from the program directors. They also participated in weekly program activities including workshops on professional skills, careers, and graduate programs; seminars from UTSA young alumni working in STEM fields; guest lectures from visiting scientists; and many more. These weekly activities also allowed the FAST scholars to form a peer network. The activities were intended to promote academic retention, development of scientific identity and self-efficacy, and sense of community among the students.

Since the program’s inception, eighteen FAST scholars have completed their bachelor’s degrees, all but one in the targeted majors. Among the remaining sixteen students, four have transferred to other schools, one transferred to another training program at UTSA, ten left the program (including two who stayed until the program ended) but are continuing at UTSA and progressing towards their degrees, and one withdrew from the university.

Among the eighteen students who have graduated, six are in graduate school, including four in STEM graduate programs and two in business school. The other twelve are either employed in STEM positions or are currently seeking such employment. As examples of our outstanding graduates, one program graduate is now pursuing a Ph.D. in Chemistry at UC San Francisco and another is pursuing a Ph.D. in Physics at UTSA. Other outstanding graduates are now working in research positions at the Southwest Research Institute and at the Texas Biomedical Research Institute.

 


Last Modified: 11/10/2021
Modified by: Kathryn M Mayer
